author: Elizabeth O'Brien
title: Retirement, Derek Jeter-style
text:
Derek Jeter loves retirement. After playing shortstop for the New York Yankees for 20 years, he retired after the 2014 season, and reportedly isn’t itching to return to help the team make the playoffs.
Instead, he’s perfectly content with a new life that centers around philanthropy, publishing and girlfriend Hannah Davis, according to media reports . New research supports his bliss: a study by researchers at Utah State University and George Mason University suggests that retirement provides an immediate boost to overall happiness and health.
A cynic might say it’s especially easy to be happy when you’ve got gobs of money in the bank and a Sports Illustrated swimsuit model on your arm. But experts say we can all learn something from how the 41-year-old Jeter has transitioned to retirement. “The mistake that many athletes, and retirees in general, make is they hit a big abyss,” said Susan Bradley, founder of the Sudden Money Institute in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and a certified financial planner who specializes in financial transitions.
Instead, Jeter has found activities that give his life purpose, structure and socialization: his charitable work with his Turn 2 Foundation and cancer organizations; his new website, The Players’ Tribune, and his girlfriend.
Jeter’s always been known as a class act. Looks like he can add retirement role model to his resume.
